title: What are the career options after 12th with PCB asides medicine? - Quora

response.answer_text: I want to start my question with something very interesting.  Millions of Indian students fail either in NEET Or IITs every year and only thousands of them move forward. First I would enlist some of the courses/career options which can be taken by 12th PCB candidate. This information is readily available on various website and portals as well. BUT THE MOST IMPORTANT THINGS I WOULD DISCUSS IN THE END ONCE YOU SEE ALL THESE OPTIONS. I WOULD TALK ABOUT THE MARKET SITUATIONS AND WHAT ACTUALLY IS HELPING AROUND IN TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND HOW TO SAFEGUARD YOUR INTEREST DURING THESE TIMES. LET’S CHECK WHAT CAN BE DONE AFTER 12TH PCB: 1. Bachelor of Ayurveda, Medicine & Surgery (B.A.M.S.): It is a five-and-a-half-year undergraduate degree course that also includes one year of internship. After successful completion of the course, students are designated as Ayurvedacharya doctor. Job Scope: Ayurveda Consultation, General Practice, Clinical Research. Relevant Courses: Master of Public Health, PG Diploma  2. Bachelor of Dental Surgery (B. D. S.): It is 5-year degree course, which includes 4 years of study followed by one year of internship. After successful completion of this degree programme, candidate is designated as Dentist. Job Scope: Lecturer, General Practice. Relevant Courses: Master of Dental Surgery, Master of Public Health  3. Bachelor of Homeopathic Medicine & Surgery (B.H.M.S.): BHMS is an undergraduate degree course of five-and-a-half-year duration (including one year compulsory internship). After successful completion of the course, students are designated as Homeopathic doctor. Job Scope: Homeopathy Consultation, General Practice, Clinical Research. Relevant Courses: Doctor of Medicine in Homeopathy, PG Diploma  4. Bachelor of Medicine & Surgery (M.B.B.S): MBBS is a five-and-a-half-year degree course which includes one year of mandatory internship in a hospital attached or approved by the concerned medical college. After successful completion of the course, students can practice Medicine & Surgery. Job Scope: Doctor, General Clinical Practice, Research. Relevant Courses: Doctor of Medicine(MD), Master of surgery (MS)  4. Bachelor of Science : Bachelor of Science is three-year degree programme offered in multitude of specializations under the pure sciences domain such as Maths, Physics, Chemistry, Botany, Zoology etc. Job Scope: BPO, SSC Exams, Graduate level exams. Relevant Courses: MSc,MA  5. Bachelor of Science Nursing : Bachelor of Science in Nursing is a four-year programme which involves classroom lessons, practical sessions as well as clinical work apart from internship. Job Scope: Employment in Hospitals & Clinics, Training institutes. Relevant Courses: MSc Nursing, Post Graduate Program in Public Health Management (PGPPHM)  6. Bachelor of Veterinary Science & Animal Husbandry (B. V. Sc. & AH): This is a five year undergraduate degree course with 6 months mandatory internship which includes training in practicing & teaching Veterinary science and livestock & poultry farm management. Job Scope: Veterinary Clinics, Zoos & Wild life Research organizations. Relevant Courses: Master of Veterinary Science, PhD (Veterinary and Animal Sciences)  7. Normal Graduation in B.A. To pursue something other than Science domain and where your actual interest lies.  As I promised that I would discuss THE MOST IMPORTANT THINGS ONCE YOU SEE ALL THESE OPTIONS. Now, I WOULD TALK ABOUT THE MARKET SITUATIONS AND WHAT ACTUALLY IS HELPING AROUND IN TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND HOW TO SAFEGUARD YOUR INTEREST DURING THESE TIMES. Bio Technology/Microbiology/In fact entire Life Sciences subjects are the poorest performing educational stream of this country as of now. Handful of jobs are available in this field.Just because one couldn’t crack NEET, should not take these branches unconsciously. THERE IS NO COMPARISON BETWEEN THESE STREAMS AND YOUR MEDICAL ASPIRATIONS.Students take these branches to avoid competition and showing that they are not the part of crowd and doing different. One thing we must accept that India is a sub continent and there are around 10000 students who think exactly the way you are thinking. Above it, the branch is having very limited employability in the market.Engineering / Medicine are no longer a career for guaranteed success. The industry scenario is changing rapidly. Now, Engineering is one of the qualifications generating more unemployed graduates.Front Page advertisements with 100 faces that got selected last year in NEET/IIT JEE do not establish that Bio and Maths are the only two lucrative career streams available in this country.Now all subjects/career options and streams like Biotechnology, Biomedical, Mechatronics and all the courses/branches which took birth in the past 10 - 20 years are having a tremendous scope. That is why they came into existence. So rather than asking for scope, the important thing to ask is how these courses/branches are performing on the ground level? What are the challenges graduates facing? Is market having enough career options available for the graduates of these courses/branches?Most important, while you shouldn't make your choice solely on an occupation's appearance on a "best careers list," because to ignore employment outlook is sheer carelessness.If possible, opt for conventional courses as they would always have their market validity. Education is one of the biggest consumer markets now. Majority of University/Colleges/Institutions (Including the so-called big brands) are clueless about their existence now. Their aim is to have as many students possible to for their existence in the market and financially profitable. Because of this, one day they may come up / launch amusing courses like: “MBA in Music Management Or MBA in Biotechnotronicsology?” It is like “you name it, we have it” But as a Parent and as a student, always stay away from fanciful experiments with your career.Find out about yourself first. Assess your personality, strengths, weaknesses etc.In short, we would strongly advise that take any of the course/stream after 12th PCB in 2 situations, 1. When you are very passionate and carve your way on your own. In this case you wouldn't ask this question at all. 2. Coming from affluent background and degree is required for marriage only. Don’t experiment with these so called new age courses/branches if: 1. Moderate family background/service class family 2. You are expected to be the bread winner as soon as you finish the college 3. On loan… Not recommended at all Broker/admission agents/counsellors at colleges/universities are having targets and they need money to live too. But its upto you to be conscious while taking any decision.  Career Consciousness is utmost required before making the most important decision of life.  We can understand it as the state of being awake, thinking, and knowing what is actually happening in the Occupations/jobs/professions that you want to pursue for a significant period of life and with the opportunities for growth. If you share this quora post, believe me it would save and impact 10 lives in your sphere of influence… I wish you all the best! Kirti

That’s a common but extremely useful question, as many people who take up PCB in class 11th have little to no clue as to what other options do they have in case they decide to not go ahead with medicine. To start off with, let me give you a little context on careers. I’m attaching a chart I made for someone asking help for non-technical careers after PCM, but I guess I can tweak it a little to suit our needs here:  As you can see (once you zoom in), the non-MEDICINE part of the chart shows you 3 most prominent career prospects should you choose to not go ahead with MBBS but still stick to the biology/chemistry stream: PHARMACY (B.Pharma - 4yrs)This is one career that is rarely affected by external factors. Whether the economy is up or down, no one ever stops taking medicine, which is why there’s a demand to fulfill by these pharma companies.In today’s times there are even 5 year Integrated Courses called MBA-Pharma Tech, which provide you a B.Pharma AND an MBA, hence saving 1 year of college and expenses (if that matters).The one important thing here is that if this is the line you choose to get into, then make sure that your interest in Chemistry is second to none.LIFE SCIENCESThese are the courses that deep-dive into the core subjects of biology from a research point of view. For example, in times like these where this Corona virus is breaking out, do you think it is the doctors who are coming up with a cure? NO! The people working on that are a mix of doctors, pharma specialists, & RESEARCHERS. These researchers can be people from various fields of study. The degree awarded for most of these courses is a BSc (3 years). However, there are prestigious research institutes like IISC, IISER, NISER, etc. which award a BS-MS degree (5 year) after their integrated courses. Some of the courses available under this:i. Zoologyii. Botanyiii. Micro-Biologyiv. Bio-Technologyv. Geneticsvi. AnthropologyFOOD & AGRICULTUREThis field is simply not just about harvesting, crops, seeds, pesticides etc., but also delves into the aspects of trading, feasibility studies, food processing, marketing as well as economics. If the prospect of getting into the management or the business side of the agriculture interests you, then the relatively new courses like BSc in Agriculture Business Management may interest you. Specializations in the field are - Food Science, Plant Science, Animal Science and Soil Science. With the demand for improvement of the food quality and production techniques it has led to a career gateway for the interested students to pursue this course. Candidates must have had Science with biology at 10+2 level for this course. Some institutions also have admissions via entrance tests. Top recruiting companies- ICRISAT, Indian Agriculture Research Institute and many more. Trending fields - Agriculture Scientists, Agronomy.Courses offered under this are:i. Food Science & Engineeringii. Horticultureiii. Agricultural Engineeringiv. Soil Sciencev. Dairy Technologyvi. Plant Breeding & Geneticsvii. Agricultural Biotechnologyviii. Agronomyix. BBA in Agricultural ScienceALLIED MEDICINEEver been to a hospital? Is it just doctors that we see there? No, right? So who are all these other people?Allied Medicine are those courses that help you work in the hospital in the capacity to assist the doctors and other specialists with their work. The degree is a BSc in the respective field of study. A few of such fields are:i. Nursesii. Radiologyiii. Optometryiv. Physiotherapyv. Nutritionist / Dietitianvi. Psychologyvii. ForensicsOther than this, there’s a whole world of careers out there that you can explore if you don’t want anything with sciences. Go back to the image above. See that section with the 5 “Technical” careers? Other than those (where either Maths or a combination of Phy+Maths is compulsory), all the “Non-Technical” careers are completely open for you as well. I think one of the other answers here has tried to cover some of them also. In any case, here’s another list of off-beat careers that are open for you despite the fact that you finished 12th with PCB: Designer (B.Des)Management (BMS)Psychologist (Psych Honours)Marketing & Advertisement (BMS / BMM / BJMC + MBA)Hospitality (Hotel Management / Tourism / etc.)Socio-Political Analyst (Pol Sci Honours / Sociology Honours / International Relations in PG / Anthropology Honours / etc.)Journalist / Editor / Content Manager (BJMC / BMM)Lawyer (BA-LLB)And that’s just the tip of the ice-berg. There’s so many things that you can do. All you need is to look inside yourself and ask yourself what is that really gets you going. Once you find your passion, there’s no stopping you from becoming whatever it is that you want to become. I think I may even have an article or two that can help clarify things a little more. If you think you want any further clarification from my end then just drop a comment and I’ll try my best to help. Regards!

Nowadays, asides medicine, there are a lot many career opportunities available for students who have opted for PCB (Physics, Chemistry, and Biology) in their class 12th. It is not necessary for class 12th PCB pass-outs to opt only for MBBS as their career option. Below I have mentioned a few of the other trending careers that requires PCB as a baseline in class 12th and has a parallel standing in terms of recognition and job openings in India and outside. Bachelor in Business Management (BBA) and Masters in Business Management (MBA): Many colleges and universities in India do not consider mathematics as a mandatory subject in order to apply for its BBA and MBA programme. Colleges like SP Jain School of Global Management or Christ University - Bangalore opens BBA for students from any stream, say with PCB.Bachelor of Science - Class 12th students with PCB can open their career prospect towards Bsc programmes like Forestry, Fishery Science ,Wildlife Marine biology, Food and Nutrition, Zoology, Food Technology, and the likes. Opting any of these Bsc courses will open various gates for PCB candidates willing to go for courses asides medicine.Bachelor of Arts (B.A.)- Students with PCB can very well opt for humanities related courses in their graduation, namely in the field of Mass Communication and Journalism, Bachelors in English leading to the designation of a Lecturer or Proof Reader can also be sought after. Also, B.Ed., CTET, or NET can be given if a student wants to indulge in the field of teaching. Alongside the above, Travel & Tourism Courses furthering the prospect of career in Tourism, Archaeology (specialization in say Medieval History offers lucrative career prospects outside India), Sociology among many others offers a range of career opportunities.Diploma Courses- Students opting for diploma courses in Merchant Navy, Event Management, Hotel Management can too indulge in a field of lucrative career prospects. Nowadays, high payroll Event Managers are on a rise. Colleges like National Academy of Event Management and Development (NAEMD) or National Institute of Event Management (NIEM) offers diploma course ‘Diploma in Event Management (DEM)’.That said, it is important to understand that following the trend is not always a smart move. What I mean to say is, opting for MBBS or BDS post your class 12th is not the only option available. Education in India is opening its door for various other career options to choose from. One can always indulge into something which is new and has a rising career opening to it, provided proper research regarding the same has been done.

From an early age, we are regularly tosed with a life-shaping, purpose-driven: " *what do you want to be when you grow up* ?" Determining what career to pursue can be an undeniably tricky task. The endeavour or thought of setting into a career can prove to be challenging or frustrating, it is important to always keep in mind that you aren't alone and we are here to help. If you're looking for a varied and rewarding career that makes a real difference to people's lives, why not take a look at a * career in Optometry ?* * Optometry is a healthcare profession that is autonomous, educated, and regulated (licensed/registered), and optometrists are the primary healthcare practitioners of the eye and visual system who provide comprehensive eye and vision care, which includes refraction and dispensing, detection/diagnosis and management of disease in the eye, and the rehabilitation of conditions of the visual system . World Council of Optometry * Courses and Duration * _Bachelor Degree Courses_ : •Bachelor of Optometry (B. Optom) ASCO: Association of Schools and Colleges of Optometry _Duration_ : 4 Years. (3years of academic +1 year of internship) _Eligibility criteria:_ You can pursue this course after completing your H.S.C/10+2 from a recognized board with physics, chemistry and biology/mathematics as your main subjects with a minimum of 50% aggregate. _Higher Education :_ •Master in Optometry •Fellowships •M.Phil. •Ph.D. _Course Content_ 1.Human Anatomy and Physiology 2.Ocular Anatomy and Physiology 3.Biochemistry 4.Physical and Geometrical optics 5.Microbiology 6.Pathology 7.Pharmacology 8.Dispensing optics 9.Ocular Diseases 10.Contact lenses 11.Low Vision 12.Binocular vision and Orthoptics 13.Instruments Apart from giving refractive correction and diagnosing visual disorders, Optometrists are specialists in many tasks performed exclusively by them, such as Vision Therapy, Low Vision Rehabilitation, Specialty Contact Lenses, Binocular Vision, Pediatric Refraction, etc. Students who want to make their career in the field of optometry must have patience, manual dexterity and confidence. The essential characteristics to become a licensed optometrist are Mechanical aptitude, good vision and coordination, self-discipline, a disposition to serve others, work ethics characterized by dedication, persistence and the ability to do that fully with patients are some essential qualities to become a successful optometrist. Credits: Team OSP Bloggers

There are lots of opportunities for PCB students except medical. Few of them are listed below: • U can go for a degree in botany and can become taxonomist, horticulturist, environmental consultant and nursery manager, etc. •A degree in zoology will pave the way for career options like lecturer, wildlife habilitation, zoologist, researcher,zoo conservator etc. • you can go for degree in nutrition and work as a nutritionist. •A degree in microbiology will give u opportunity to work as microbiologist, clinical research consultant, you can work in breweries, food industries and distelliries etc. • biochemistry also have many options like as graduate of biochemistry you will be able to work for improving the process of photosynthesis to increase crop yield, research for biofeuls , biomedical scientist, forsensic scientist, toxicologist, medical coder etc. •degree in environmental science is also an option. You can be hired as environmentalist, environmental scientist are also hired for research and various other roles in industries like mines, water treatment plants, fertiliser plants etc. •as a genetics student u can work as immunologist, DNA genesist etc. •you can also opt for marine biology course it will give employment opportunities like aquaculturist, fishery biologist etc. These are some of the options but there are many more opportunities.

There are homeopathic, ayurvedic, alternative medicine courses,agriculture, etc. But in pure sciences there are not plenty but quite a few options. Eligibility Criteria UoH has an integrated course which is VERY GOOD. OPEN FOR PCB but has maths in its ENTRANCE EXAM. all 4 subjects (including MATH).. you can even find question papers online. (check out the systems biology course - maybe the first for UG)Similar integrated MSc courses are offered in various universities and research institutes which are good.. check out for them in research institutes' websites.. one example is here Integrated M.Sc. Programme Highlights - Institute of Life Sciences the iisc programme is very prestigious.. but needs a math background as in mpc. so i suppose will do only if you have a pcmb  IISc UG - Information Brochure IISERs are very promising because there are more number of seats. Here again they take both pcm and pub but exam will have all pcmb subjects. SO U HAVE TO LEARN MATHS FOR THE PAPER IISER Admission 2015 Apart from these you can take up BSc courses in zoology, botany and the like. The ones cited above offer Biology as such. You could consider going abroad - will be costly but there are many scholarships for foreign students especially for non medical courses like boomed and biotech.. but for science equally good opportunities are there here :)All the best :D

People generally think about you as a medical aspirant, if you choose biology as a subject. Rather, they don't know that there are many more branches that are biology related and thus fail to value degrees other than medical. A double degree in Biology (B.Sc and M.Sc) can make you eligible for post of a teacher in schools or lecturer in degree colleges. You can also do side-by-side research some topic, obtain P.Hd and be at a higher post! You can have scope in heading organisations and research institutes if do do good in your field. A B.Tech degree in Biotechnology is also of much importance. You can be related to improving agriculture methods like effective fertilizer development. Research on use of microbes and bacteria is taking progress as their importance is building up. So likewise, if you just google up, you can find several career opinions related to biology, other than medical, and there is a lot of chance of progress in these fields. All the best!

It’s nice that there are people in the country who are interested in specialization in basic sciences and not MBBS aspirants(as I am a MBBS apsirant :P ) I’ll give you a list of exams and the courses offered by various institutions, if you get a good score in the entrances. KVPY(Kishore Vygyanik Protsahan Yojna)- If you qualify in this, you can get in to IISc Bangalore, where you can do BSc and then MSc. It’s a very very prestigious place and you have a work a lot for KVPY!NEST(National Entrance Screening Test)- It is also a national level exam where you are offered 5 year intergrated BSc+MSc in basic sciences in either UM-DAE, Mumbai or NISER, Bhubaneshwar (You can have more information about it in it’s offcial website).NEET(National Eligibility Entrance Test) - This is not only for MBBS. You can get into any good university for BSc in basic sciences or BTech in biotechnology or Genetics through your NEET rankAccording to my knowledge, these three are useful for a PCB student, who is not into MBBS. Note: All these exams need immense hard work and dedication. It’s easy to aspire but it’s really hard to get into these prestigious universities. All the very best :)

Career options are not certain until you find your passion. What are the things you love to do will show how much you are going to enjoy and love your work. Let's look at the career opportunities after the 12th class: 1. Horticulturist (2 - 28 lakhs per annum) 2. Dermatologist (6 lakhs per annum +) 3. Dentist (4 to 6 lakhs per annum +) 4. Molecular biology (3 to 4 lakhs per annum +) 5. Pharmacist (3 to 10 lakhs per annum easily +) 6. Physiotherapist (3 lakhs per annum to 10 lakhs per annum +) 7. Podiatrist (8 Lakhs per annum +) 8. Psychiatrist (12-15 lakhs per annum+) 9. Psychologist (12-20 lakhs per annum+) 10. Veterinarian (10-20 lakhs per annum) 11. Nurse 12. Medical Technologist 13. Homeopath 14. Forensic scientist (8 to 10 lakhs per annum +)  I wish you all the very best. Do Wonders :) If this answer was helpful, do upvote for maximum reach :)

Most of the people have a general perception that all PCB students aspire to become doctors. But its definitely not true. There are ALOT of career options besides medicine. If you want to do something within the Science stream itself : B.Sc. in Botany, Zoology, Biotechnology, Biochemistry, MicrobiologyForensic Science (upcoming and in-demand)Paramedical Sciences - like Audiology, Speech Therapist, RadiographyBAMS/BUMS/BHMSB.Sc. in Food TechnologyOtherwise you can go in for other promising options like : LawJournalism and Mass CommunicationDesigning (NIFT/NID)Psychology/Sociology HonsThere is scope in each and every field. It just depends on how well you take it. :)

Thank you for Asking! Courses for students with PCB subjects: MBBSBDSB.Pharmacy.B.A.M.S.Pharm.D.Bsc NursingB.H.M.S.Bachelor of PhysiotherapyOther Bsc CoursesDiploma coursesB.U.M.S.B.A.S.L.P.Management coursesTeaching & Education coursesJob Oriented courses you may pursue- Air Hostess trainingEvent management coursesHospitality Diploma coursesLawAnimation, Graphics and MultimediaFashion Technology/DesignJournalism and Mass CommunicationWeb Development and DesigningHope this helps you!

If student has a keen interest in Biology but does not want to become a doctor, then they can explore Genetics as a career option. Genetics is the study of heredity and genetic variations. A geneticist’s primary task is to conduct research involving genes. They work in varied fields- from university to hospitals, from the pharmaceutical industry to agriculture and so on. Students need to a Bachelors in Life Sciences followed by an M. Sc and PhD in Genetics. Starting salary for freshers is in the range of Rs. 3.12 Lakh and onwards per annum. There are a lot more career opportunities for those who have aptitude in Biology but don’t want to pursue medicine. For more career options please reach us @ 9895455730 or 9446657657. Team Auracle

And yes is best for abroad ones.ArmyLecturer in govt. Institutes after bscAnd many more but I think the above ones are the best. To know more on anything write me I m really obliged to help you. And dont forget to follow me on quora for more interesting answers…!!

Apart from medical, you can go for Biotechnology, Bio medical engineering, Bioinformatics, Medical Microbiology, Bachelor of Physiotherapy, Environmental Science, Nanotechnology, Clinical Research, Psychology, Counsellor, Agriculture Science, Veterinary Science, etc Rest it depends upon your strength, skills and interest where you wanna utilize your skills.So choose wisely.

Instead of becoming a doctor you can do these things- 1.Agriculture 2.Research work 3.PHD and then lecturer or professor. 4.Open a nursery business in this way you will be connected to your subject a bit. 5.pharmacy 6.biotechnology 7.dairy science

Beside Mbbs y can pursue following courses : BDS BAMS BHMS BUMS (if studied Urdu in 10+2 level) Veterinary ( there are pretty Gud chances for job security since there is going to be lot of vacancy... Since from a long time there is no posting in this sector..Also if you love field work n if you love to serve animals) B. Sc. (micro,biotech,forensic etc. ) B. Pharma B. Tech (Agri.)

There are many options other than MBBS. Conventionally, people opt for Dentistry , Vertinary Science, Agricultural Science and so on. Alternatively, you can pursue fields like biochemistry, Microbiology, Forensic Medicine, physiology, botany,Zoology and so on. These fields have an Academic and research outlook. You can even opt for physiotherapy, Nursing science or Ayurveda, Naturopathy, homeopathy etc. There are endless possibilities. All the best.

Pharmacolgy, Paramedical Professions, Degree studies in anyone or more of the PCB Group subjects, Veterinary and Animal Husbandry, Agriculture, and so on.. there are many options for you with PCB at +2 stage.
Check for medical physicist
There are many other courses like BAMS Biotech B.tech(agriculture) Bsc Some medicinal courses are also available… Best of luck

There are certain stream neutral options for students with PCB in class 12th other than medicine. These are: LawManagementHotel ManagementDesigningMass CommunicationGet Personalised Counseling by Experts at PRATHAM Test Prep.

Depends. Best for you or best for him? The Best field is the one he loves and he is more interested.  We know nothing about your son and his interests, so it is very hard to make recommendations. If he likes to build things, perhaps engineering.  If he likes to debate, perhaps, law, and if he likes to read any book he can find, perhaps something in the Humanities. Your son should talk to his teachers and friends and family with different professions and then decide.
Well you can opt for physiotherapy, or PhD if you really wanna be a doctor. Other than that go for DU, pharma, paramedical courses
